questions.text: Study of all aspects of death is called as: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Thanatology

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thanatology is the field that comprehensively studies death and the various aspects associated with it.

questions.text: An HIV patient presents with fever and neck stiffness. Lumbar puncture was done and CSF examination shows lymphocytosis, normal glucose, increased protein and positive India ink staining. What is likely causative organism? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cryptococcus neoformans

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The correct answer is Cryptococcus neoformans. The patient presents with signs of meningitis (fever, neck stiffness) and has a cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) profile showing lymphocytosis, normal glucose, increased protein, and positive India ink staining.
  • • Cryptococcal meningitis is a common opportunistic infection in HIV patients and is diagnosed by the presence of encapsulated yeast cells seen on India ink staining.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Pneumocystis jirovecii: This organism typically causes pneumonia rather than meningitis.
  • • Option B. Pneumocystis jirovecii:
  • • Option C. Tuberculosis: Tuberculous meningitis usually presents with low glucose levels in the CSF, which is not the case here.
  • • Option C. Tuberculosis:
  • • Option D. Pneumococcus: Pneumococcal meningitis typically presents with a neutrophilic CSF rather than lymphocytic CSF.
  • • Option D. Pneumococcus:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cryptococcus neoformans is a common cause of meningitis in HIV patients, characterized by lymphocytic CSF, normal glucose, increased protein, and positive India ink staining, which reveals encapsulated yeast cells. ​

questions.text: Which of the following is an opsonin? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) C3b

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ C3b is an opsonin important in the immune system for marking pathogens for phagocytosis, enhancing the body's ability to clear infections.

questions.text: By which cell of Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia/Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma arises? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Naive B cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma arises from naive B cells or post-germinal center memory B cells, distinguishing it from other B-cell and T-cell malignancies.

questions.text: A patient presents at 36 weeks with chronic HTN and 3+ proteinuria. Her BP is 170/100 mmHg and she complains of headache and blurring of vision. What is the best management option? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Labetalol + MgSO4 + Expedite delivery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of severe preeclampsia after 34 weeks, immediate delivery, blood pressure control with labetalol, and seizure prophylaxis with magnesium sulfate are essential for optimal maternal and fetal outcomes.

questions.text: A 12-year-old presented with fever and difficulty swallowing. He had swelling in the marked region and was advised to undergo surgery. Post-surgery the gauze continued to soak with blood. Which of the following vessels must have been injured? ( INICET May 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Paratonsillar vein

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In the case described, the patient likely underwent surgery for a peritonsillar abscess (aka Quinsy), a complication arising from tonsillitis. This condition can lead to significant swelling in the throat and difficulty swallowing. Post-operative bleeding in such cases, especially the continuous type noted as soaking through gauze, is most commonly associated with venous sources rather than arterial.
  • • The given image is a cadaveric specimen with an arrow pointing to the tonsillar fossa. The paratonsillar / external palatine vein is the typical site of venous origin for post-tonsillectomy bleeding.
  • • The paratonsillar vein, which is closely associated with the tonsillar bed and provides significant venous drainage for the tonsil, is the likely source of this bleeding. Venous bleeding tends to be continuous and can be persistent if the vein is not adequately secured during surgery.
  • • Torrential hemorrhage can be due to injury to an aberrantly large or aberrantly placed tonsillar arterial branch of the facial artery.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Tonsillar branch of the facial artery : The tonsils receive blood supply primarily from the tonsillar branch of the facial artery. Injury to this artery during tonsillar surgery can cause bleeding, but the bleeding is usually brisk and bright red, and the artery would likely be cauterized or ligated during surgery to prevent such bleeding.
  • • Option A.
  • • Tonsillar branch of the facial artery
  • • Option B . Ascending pharyngeal artery : It's a branch of the external carotid artery and supplies the pharynx, soft palate, and the tympanic cavity. While this artery does provide blood supply to the pharyngeal region, it's not as intimately associated with the tonsillar region as the tonsillar branch of the facial artery.
  • • Option B
  • • Ascending pharyngeal artery
  • • Option D . Retromandibular vein : The retromandibular vein is formed by the union of the superficial temporal vein and the maxillary vein in the parotid gland. It's located further away from the tonsillar region, and it's unlikely to be injured during procedures involving the tonsils.
  • • Option D
  • • Retromandibular vein

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Blood supply of the tonsils:
  • ➤ Blood supply of the tonsils:
  • ➤ Arterial supply:
  • ➤ Arterial supply:
  • ➤ The tonsillar branch of the facial artery is the main supply. Ascending palatine branch of the facial artery.
  • ➤ The tonsillar branch of the facial artery is the main supply.
  • ➤ Ascending palatine branch of the facial artery.
  • ➤ Venous supply:
  • ➤ Venous supply:
  • ➤ Veins from the tonsils drain into paratonsillar vein which joins the common facial vein and pharyngeal venous plexus.
  • ➤ Veins from the tonsils drain into paratonsillar vein which joins the common facial vein and pharyngeal venous plexus.
  • ➤ Types of Hemorrhage seen during/post tonsillectomy:
  • ➤ Types of Hemorrhage seen during/post tonsillectomy:
  • ➤ 1. Primary hemorrhage:
  • ➤ 1. Primary hemorrhage:
  • ➤ Occurs during surgery due to injury to blood vessels. Can be controlled by pressure, ligation, or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels.
  • ➤ Occurs during surgery due to injury to blood vessels.
  • ➤ Can be controlled by pressure, ligation, or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels.
  • ➤ 2. Reactionary hemorrhage:
  • ➤ 2. Reactionary hemorrhage:
  • ➤ It occurs within 24 hours of surgery. It may be due to dislodgement of the clot, slippage of ligature, or return of blood pressure to normal. It is managed by removal of clot and application of pressure or vasoconstrictor. If not controlled the patient is anesthetized and hemorrhage is managed by re-exploration.
  • ➤ It occurs within 24 hours of surgery.
  • ➤ It may be due to dislodgement of the clot, slippage of ligature, or return of blood pressure to normal.
  • ➤ It is managed by removal of clot and application of pressure or vasoconstrictor.
  • ➤ If not controlled the patient is anesthetized and hemorrhage is managed by re-exploration.
  • ➤ 3. Secondary hemorrhage:
  • ➤ 3. Secondary hemorrhage:
  • ➤ It occurs between 24 hours to 10 days (most common between 5th to 8th postoperative days). It is due to sepsis and premature separation of the membrane. The patient is started on IV antibiotics and if not controlled, general anesthesia is given and the bleeding vessel is electrocoagulated or ligated.
  • ➤ It occurs between 24 hours to 10 days (most common between 5th to 8th postoperative days).
  • ➤ It is due to sepsis and premature separation of the membrane.
  • ➤ The patient is started on IV antibiotics and if not controlled, general anesthesia is given and the bleeding vessel is electrocoagulated or ligated.

questions.text: The time gap between entry of organism in human body and its maximal infectivity is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Generation time

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Generation time is the interval between the entry of an organism into the body and the point of maximal infectivity.

questions.text: Which of the following are vitamin-B12 dependent enzymes? ( INICET Nov 2020) Methylmalonyl Co isomerase Homocysteine synthase Folate reductase Methionine synthase
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1 and 4 only

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The enzymes methylmalonyl CoA isomerase and methionine synthase are dependent on vitamin B12. These enzymes play critical roles in metabolic pathways, including amino acid catabolism and methylation reactions.

questions.text: Identify the parameter seen in all types of shock: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Decreased Tissue Perfusion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Decreased tissue perfusion is a universal characteristic of all types of shock, leading to inadequate oxygen and nutrient delivery to tissues.

questions.text: Best method for detection of mutations with low allele frequency is? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Droplet digital PCR

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented to the dermatologist with a small lesion on her right nasolabial fold. Upon examination, the dermatologist noted a 0.4-cm nodule with a smooth surface and well-defined borders. The nodule was located on the upper forehead, just above the eyebrows. It was excised and a pathological examination was done. The image is given below. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Basal cell carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Basal cell carcinoma is the most common type of skin cancer and is typically found in sun-exposed areas. It appears as a pearly nodule with visible blood vessels and can cause significant local destruction if left untreated. Mohs micrographic surgery is an effective treatment, particularly for tumors in cosmetically sensitive areas.
  • ➤ Basal cell carcinoma is the most common type of skin cancer and is typically found in sun-exposed areas.
  • ➤ It appears as a pearly nodule with visible blood vessels and can cause significant local destruction if left untreated.
  • ➤ Mohs micrographic surgery is an effective treatment, particularly for tumors in cosmetically sensitive areas.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the given image? (NEET PG 2018)

options.label: C
options.text: It is associated with facial angiofibroma

options.label: D
options.text: They are associated with a neurocutaneous syndrome

questions.correct_answer: C. It is associated with facial angiofibroma
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It is associated with facial angiofibroma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of Lisch nodules on the iris is associated with for Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1) and is not associated with facial angiofibroma, which is seen in characteristic of Tuberous Sclerosis Complex, not NF1.

questions.text: Which of the following is deficient in a patient with phenylketonuria with normal phenylalanine hydroxylase levels? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: What does the ECG show? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  B) P pulmonale

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ P pulmonale, indicated by tall P waves greater than 2.5 mm in lead II, signifies right atrial enlargement commonly due to pulmonary hypertension or other pulmonary conditions leading to increased right atrial pressure.

questions.text: A 34 year G2P1 presents at 35 weeks. She has no complaints and is appreciating fetal movements well. She had a previous classical cesarean at 25 weeks for eclampsia and severe FGR. She is currently on low dose aspirin and prenatal vitamins. On examination, the uterus is SFH is 38 cm and FHR is 140 bpm. An ultrasound reveals a single live fetus in breech presentation, placenta posterior and amniotic fluid normal. The patient desires a vaginal delivery. What is the best management? (NEET PG 2022)

options.label: D
options.text: Await spontaneous labor and then do an internal podalic version

questions.correct_answer: B. Schedule elective LSCS at 37 weeks
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Schedule elective LSCS at 37 weeks

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Schedule elective LSCS at 37 weeks: The patient has a history of a classical cesarean section, which is an absolute contraindication to vaginal delivery due to the high risk of uterine rupture. A classical cesarean section involves a vertical incision on the upper part of the uterus, which does not heal as strongly as the lower segment horizontal incision, leading to a higher risk of rupture during labor. Given the breech presentation and the patient's obstetric history, an elective cesarean section at 37 weeks is the safest option to prevent complications.
  • • Schedule elective LSCS at 37 weeks: The patient has a history of a classical cesarean section, which is an absolute contraindication to vaginal delivery due to the high risk of uterine rupture. A classical cesarean section involves a vertical incision on the upper part of the uterus, which does not heal as strongly as the lower segment horizontal incision, leading to a higher risk of rupture during labor. Given the breech presentation and the patient's obstetric history, an elective cesarean section at 37 weeks is the safest option to prevent complications.
  • • Schedule elective LSCS at 37 weeks:
  • • The patient has a history of a classical cesarean section, which is an absolute contraindication to vaginal delivery due to the high risk of uterine rupture. A classical cesarean section involves a vertical incision on the upper part of the uterus, which does not heal as strongly as the lower segment horizontal incision, leading to a higher risk of rupture during labor. Given the breech presentation and the patient's obstetric history, an elective cesarean section at 37 weeks is the safest option to prevent complications.
  • • The patient has a history of a classical cesarean section, which is an absolute contraindication to vaginal delivery due to the high risk of uterine rupture.
  • • A classical cesarean section involves a vertical incision on the upper part of the uterus, which does not heal as strongly as the lower segment horizontal incision, leading to a higher risk of rupture during labor.
  • • Given the breech presentation and the patient's obstetric history, an elective cesarean section at 37 weeks is the safest option to prevent complications.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Review USG after 2 weeks: This option does not address the critical issue of the patient's previous classical cesarean section, which necessitates planning for a repeat cesarean delivery.
  • • Option A. Review USG after 2 weeks:
  • • Option C. ECV at 36 weeks: External Cephalic Version (ECV) is contraindicated in patients with a previous classical cesarean section due to the increased risk of uterine rupture.
  • • Option C. ECV at 36 weeks:
  • • Option D. Await spontaneous labor and then do an internal podalic version: Awaiting spontaneous labor is not advisable due to the increased risk of uterine rupture with a classical cesarean scar. Additionally, internal podalic version is not a recommended procedure in this context.
  • • Option D. Await spontaneous labor and then do an internal podalic version:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A classical cesarean section is an absolute contraindication to a vaginal delivery due to the high risk of uterine rupture; hence, an elective cesarean section should be scheduled at 37 weeks.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1439, William Obstetrics, 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1439, William Obstetrics, 26 th edition

questions.text: A patient came to the medical OPD with complaints of polyuria. He has a history of undergoing total hypophysectomy. His Na + levels are found to be 155 mEq/L, urine osmolality was 200 mOsm/L. What is the definitive management? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: DDAVP for 2 weeks and then discontinue

options.label: C
options.text: Upsetting of receptors so no treatment is required

questions.explanation:
Ans. B. DDAVP supplementation for lifelong

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with central diabetes insipidus following total hypophysectomy, lifelong desmopressin (DDAVP) supplementation is required to manage symptoms and prevent complications from persistent polyuria and hypernatremia.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) involves skin-to-skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding, and early discharge, focusing on the care of low birthweight infants.

(INICET MAY 2023) Failure to attain menarche by 15 years of age Failure to attain menarche even after 3 years of thelarche High levels of TSH and short stature Failure of development of breasts by 13 years of age
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Primary amenorrhea should be considered if there is failure to attain menarche by 15 years of age, failure to attain menarche even after 3 years of thelarche, or failure of breast development by 13 years of age.

questions.text: A 35-year-old Farmer on maize diet with diarrhoea, dementia, and dermatitis. Which Vitamin is deficient in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Niacin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The major protein of Maize, “Zein” lacks tryptophan which is required for Niacin biosynthesis. 60 mg of tryptophan gives 1 mg of Niacin in the body. So, pellagra is more common when maize is the staple diet due to decreased synthesis of Niacin. Pellagra is characterized by 3Ds i.e. diarrhoea, dementia and dermatitis. Death and delirium and depression can also occur.
  • ➤ Pellagra can also be caused due to Isoniazid therapy as isoniazid inhibits PLP (B6) formation which in turn is required for Niacin synthesis. Vitamin B2 is also required for Niacin synthesis, so, a deficiency either of B2 or B6 or both can cause pellagra.
  • ➤ Thiamine (B1) deficiency leads to Beri-Beri. CNS and CVS are affected in dry Beri-Beri and wet Beri-Beri respectively.
  • ➤ Main symptoms of Riboflavin deficiency are Cheilosis, Glossitis and Corneal vascularization.
  • ➤ Pyridoxine deficiency cause anemia (microcytic, hypochromic) and seizures in infants.
  • ➤ Ref -Harper 31 st e/pg. 534-535
  • ➤ Ref -Harper 31 st e/pg. 534-535

questions.text: Sympathetic ophthalmia is a consequence of which of the following?

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sympathetic ophthalmia is a preventable and treatable condition if diagnosed early and managed appropriately. Awareness of its presentation and prompt treatment can prevent severe bilateral vision loss.

questions.text: Which of the following complication is specific to Monochorionic twins? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.correct_answer: C. Twin to twin transfusion syndrome
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Twin to twin transfusion syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Complications specific to monochorionic twins are:
  • • Twin to twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) : This is a specific complication seen in monochorionic twins. There is a donor twin and a recipient twin; the donor is anemic and pale with oligohydramnios, while the recipient is polycythemic and may have circulatory overload, ascites, and hydrops. Quintero's staging is used for TTTS, and the treatment involves laser ablation of vessels. TRAP sequence (Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion) : This is another specific complication seen in monochorionic twins, involving an acardiac twin.
  • • Twin to twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) : This is a specific complication seen in monochorionic twins. There is a donor twin and a recipient twin; the donor is anemic and pale with oligohydramnios, while the recipient is polycythemic and may have circulatory overload, ascites, and hydrops. Quintero's staging is used for TTTS, and the treatment involves laser ablation of vessels.
  • • Twin to twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS)
  • • TRAP sequence (Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion) : This is another specific complication seen in monochorionic twins, involving an acardiac twin.
  • • TRAP sequence (Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Selective fetal growth restriction : While this can occur in monochorionic twins, it is not specific to them.
  • • Option A. Selective fetal growth restriction
  • • Option B. Polyhydramnios : This can be seen in various conditions and is not specific to monochorionic twins.
  • • Option B. Polyhydramnios
  • • Option D. Neural tube defects : These can occur in any pregnancy and are not specific to monochorionic twins.
  • • Option D. Neural tube defects
  • • Thus, options A, B, and D are not specific complications of monochorionic twins.
  • • Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24 th edition pg904,905
  • • Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24 th edition pg904,905

questions.text: Apolipoprotein B 48 is a made of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) RNA editing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In liver cell, Apo B100 gene gives rise to Apo B 100 protein. But Apo B48 protein is made in intestinal cells from the gene encoding Apo B100, by the process of RNA editing, which is also known as Differential RNA processing or chemical modification of RNA. This is a post transcriptional modification.
  • ➤ Ref- Harper 31st ed pg – 238
  • ➤ Ref- Harper 31st ed pg – 238

  • • This is a rare genetic disorder characterized by extreme sensitivity to ultraviolet (UV) rays from sunlight, leading to an increased risk of skin cancer.
  • • This is a rare genetic disorder characterized by extreme sensitivity to ultraviolet (UV) rays from sunlight, leading to an increased risk of skin cancer.

  • • The lesions associated with this condition are more freckle-like and do not resemble the thick, velvety texture seen in the image.
  • • The lesions associated with this condition are more freckle-like and do not resemble the thick, velvety texture seen in the image.

  • • Option D. Café au lait spots
  • • These are light brown to dark brown spots commonly associated with neurofibromatosis or McCune-Albright syndrome .
  • • These are light brown to dark brown spots commonly associated with neurofibromatosis or McCune-Albright syndrome .
  • • light brown to dark brown spots
  • • neurofibromatosis or McCune-Albright syndrome
  • • Unlike Acanthosis Nigricans, café au lait spots are smooth in texture and uniform in pigmentation, not velvety or thickened.
  • • Unlike Acanthosis Nigricans, café au lait spots are smooth in texture and uniform in pigmentation, not velvety or thickened.

  • ➤ neck

  • ➤ Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9 th edition Page no 87.2
  • ➤ Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9 th edition Page no 87.2

questions.text: Which type of amyloidosis is more likely to develop in a patient undergoing long-term hemodialysis due to renal failure? ( INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Amyloid β2 microglobulin (Aβ2M)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Long-term hemodialysis patients with renal failure may experience the development of amyloidosis due to the accumulation of Aβ2-microglobulin.
  • ➤ Additional Information
  • ➤ Additional Information
  • ➤ A. Generalized/Systemic Amyloidosis
  • ➤ A. Generalized/Systemic Amyloidosis
  • ➤ B. Localised Amyloidosis
  • ➤ B. Localised Amyloidosis
  • ➤ C. Hereditary Amyloidosis
  • ➤ C. Hereditary Amyloidosis

questions.text: A patient with pauci-immune crescentic glomerulonephritis, palpable purpura, myalgia, and pulmonary hemorrhage was found to have p-ANCA positivity. Which of the following is the likely vasculitis in him? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Microscopic polyangiitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA) is a small-vessel vasculitis associated with p-ANCA positivity and multi-organ involvement, including the kidneys, skin, muscles, and lungs

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presented at 7 weeks of gestation, unwilling to continue the pregnancy. What are the drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy in this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Misoprostol and Mifepristone

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Misoprostol and Mifepristone : The drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) in this patient presenting at 7 weeks of gestation are misoprostol and mifepristone. Mifepristone 200 mg is administered orally on day 1. It acts as an antiprogestogen, blocking the effects of progesterone, which is essential to maintain pregnancy. Misoprostol is given 24-48 hours after mifepristone. Misoprostol, a prostaglandin E1 analog, induces uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy tissue. Clinical confirmation of MTP is done on day 14 through clinical examination and/or ultrasonography to ensure the complete expulsion of the products of conception.
  • • Misoprostol and Mifepristone : The drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) in this patient presenting at 7 weeks of gestation are misoprostol and mifepristone. Mifepristone 200 mg is administered orally on day 1. It acts as an antiprogestogen, blocking the effects of progesterone, which is essential to maintain pregnancy. Misoprostol is given 24-48 hours after mifepristone. Misoprostol, a prostaglandin E1 analog, induces uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy tissue. Clinical confirmation of MTP is done on day 14 through clinical examination and/or ultrasonography to ensure the complete expulsion of the products of conception.
  • • Misoprostol and Mifepristone
  • • The drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) in this patient presenting at 7 weeks of gestation are misoprostol and mifepristone. Mifepristone 200 mg is administered orally on day 1. It acts as an antiprogestogen, blocking the effects of progesterone, which is essential to maintain pregnancy. Misoprostol is given 24-48 hours after mifepristone. Misoprostol, a prostaglandin E1 analog, induces uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy tissue. Clinical confirmation of MTP is done on day 14 through clinical examination and/or ultrasonography to ensure the complete expulsion of the products of conception.
  • • The drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) in this patient presenting at 7 weeks of gestation are misoprostol and mifepristone.
  • • Mifepristone 200 mg is administered orally on day 1. It acts as an antiprogestogen, blocking the effects of progesterone, which is essential to maintain pregnancy.
  • • Misoprostol is given 24-48 hours after mifepristone. Misoprostol, a prostaglandin E1 analog, induces uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy tissue.
  • • Clinical confirmation of MTP is done on day 14 through clinical examination and/or ultrasonography to ensure the complete expulsion of the products of conception.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Misoprostol and Medroxyprogesterone : Medroxyprogesterone is a synthetic progestin used in contraception and hormone replacement therapy but is not used in medical termination of pregnancy.
  • • Option A. Misoprostol and Medroxyprogesterone
  • • Option C. Mifepristone and Methotrexate : Methotrexate is a folate antagonist that can be used in combination with misoprostol for medical termination of pregnancy, especially in early gestations, but it is not the standard regimen compared to mifepristone and misoprostol.
  • • Option C. Mifepristone and Methotrexate
  • • Option D. Mifepristone and Medroxyprogesterone : Medroxyprogesterone is not used in medical termination of pregnancy.
  • • Option D. Mifepristone and Medroxyprogesterone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For medical termination of pregnancy at 7 weeks of gestation, the recommended drugs are mifepristone followed by misoprostol.
  • ➤ Ref: https://main.mohfw.gov.in/acts-rules-and-standards-health-sector/acts/mtp-rules
  • ➤ Ref: https://main.mohfw.gov.in/acts-rules-and-standards-health-sector/acts/mtp-rules

questions.text: Identify the type of ANA staining pattern shown in the image below: ( INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Centromeric

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The centromeric ANA staining pattern is associated with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (CREST syndrome) and is characterized by discrete speckles aligned with chromosomes in dividing cells.

questions.text: Match the following poisons and their probable mechanism of action: ( INICET Nov 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. A-2, B-4, C-1, D-3

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A. Zinc chloride :
  • • A. Zinc chloride
  • • Mechanism: Irritant Explanation: Zinc chloride is a chemical compound known to cause erosive esophagitis and irritation to the eyes and mucous membranes.
  • • Mechanism: Irritant
  • • Mechanism:
  • • Explanation: Zinc chloride is a chemical compound known to cause erosive esophagitis and irritation to the eyes and mucous membranes.
  • • Explanation:
  • • B. Chloral hydrate :
  • • B. Chloral hydrate
  • • Mechanism: Stupefying (CNS depressant) Explanation: Chloral hydrate is a central nervous system depressant used historically as a sedative and hypnotic agent.
  • • Mechanism: Stupefying (CNS depressant)
  • • Mechanism:
  • • Explanation: Chloral hydrate is a central nervous system depressant used historically as a sedative and hypnotic agent.
  • • Explanation:
  • • C. Quinine :
  • • C. Quinine
  • • Mechanism: Abortifacient Explanation: Quinine has been used historically to induce abortion, although its use in this context is highly dangerous and not recommended.
  • • Mechanism: Abortifacient
  • • Mechanism:
  • • Explanation: Quinine has been used historically to induce abortion, although its use in this context is highly dangerous and not recommended.
  • • Explanation:
  • • D. Potassium carbonate :
  • • D. Potassium carbonate
  • • Mechanism: Corrosive Explanation: Potassium carbonate is an alkali that has a corrosive action on tissues, causing chemical burns upon contact.
  • • Mechanism: Corrosive
  • • Mechanism:
  • • Explanation: Potassium carbonate is an alkali that has a corrosive action on tissues, causing chemical burns upon contact.

questions.text: Identify the most important risk factor for acute mastitis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cracked nipple

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of cracks and fissures in the nipples is the most important risk factor for acute mastitis due to the direct pathway it provides for bacterial entry.

questions.text: In the medical management of glaucoma, drugs which decrease the intraocular pressure are indicated. Which of the following drugs decreases intraocular pressure by increasing uveoscleral flow? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Latanoprost

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Latanoprost, a prostaglandin analogue, lowers intraocular pressure by increasing the uveoscleral outflow of aqueous humor, making it an effective treatment option for glaucoma.
